content: The Act is titled the "Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009" and defines key terms. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to define "private fund" as an issuer exempt from being an investment company under certain sections, and "foreign private fund adviser" as an adviser without a US place of business. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 defines a "foreign private fund adviser" as an adviser without a US place of business, with fewer than 15 clients in the US and assets under management of less than $25,000,000. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 defines a "foreign private fund adviser" as an adviser without a US place of business, with fewer than 15 clients in the US and assets under management of less than $25,000,000. Additionally, the adviser must not hold itself out as an investment adviser to any registered investment company or business development company in the US. SEC. 3. ELIMINATION OF PRIVATE ADVISER EXEMPTION; LIMITED EXEMPTION FOR FOREIGN PRIVATE FUND ADVISERS; LIMITED INTRASTATE EXEMPTION. Section 203(b) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers, such as small business investment companies licensed under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 and entities approved by the Small Business Administration. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for small business investment companies applying for licenses that have not been revoked or have pending license applications. SEC. 4. COLLECTION OF SYSTEMIC RISK DATA. Section 204 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require investment advisers to maintain records and file reports with the Commission regarding private funds advised by them. The Commission is authorized to provide reports or records to entities identified as having systemic risk responsibility for the assessment of systemic risk. The records and reports required for private funds advised by an investment adviser include assets under management, leverage usage, and counterparty credit risk exposures. The SEC may require private funds to report information such as assets under management, leverage, counterparty credit risk exposures, trading and investment positions, trading practices, and other relevant details for the protection of investors and assessment of systemic risk. Additionally, the Commission has the option to request additional information from private funds. The SEC may set different reporting requirements for private fund advisers based on fund types or sizes. Investment advisers must maintain records of private funds for specified periods as determined by the Commission. The SEC may set reporting requirements for private fund advisers. Investment advisers must maintain records of private funds for specified periods for examinations by the Commission. The SEC requires investment advisers to maintain and provide records to the Commission upon request, including sharing information with other entities identified for systemic risk responsibility. The SEC mandates investment advisers to share reports and information with entities responsible for assessing systemic risk of private funds, ensuring confidentiality as per Commission guidelines. Investment advisers must provide reports, records, and documents to investors, counterparties, and creditors of private funds as required by the SEC for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. The Commission is not obligated to disclose any confidential reports or information. The SEC is required to disclose reports and information filed with them, but they cannot withhold information from Congress or other federal agencies. They must comply with requests for information within their jurisdiction and court orders. The SEC must disclose reports and information filed with them, cannot withhold information from Congress or federal agencies, and must comply with requests within their jurisdiction and court orders. The United States or the Commission is considered a statute under section 552 of title 5, United States Code. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to eliminate a disclosure provision in Section 210. Additionally, there is an exemption and reporting requirement for venture capital fund advisers in Section 6. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide an exemption for venture capital fund advisers from registration requirements, with reporting obligations to the Commission. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to exempt venture capital fund advisers from registration requirements, with reporting obligations to the Commission. This exemption is deemed appropriate in the public interest or for the protection of investors. SEC. 7. EXEMPTION OF AND REPORTING BY CERTAIN PRIVATE FUND ADVISERS. Section 203 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide an exemption from registration requirements for investment advisers of private funds with assets under management in the US of less than $150,000,000. The Commission will also require exempted advisers to maintain reporting. Advisers exempted from registration requirements must maintain records and provide necessary reports to the Commission. The Commission will consider the size, governance, and investment strategy of mid-sized private funds to determine systemic risk and provide regulations accordingly. The Commission will determine systemic risk posed by investment advisers of private funds and establish registration and examination procedures accordingly. SEC. 8. CLARIFICATION OF RULEMAKING AUTHORITY. Section 211 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to grant the Commission authority to make, amend, and rescind rules and regulations necessary for its functions, including defining technical terms and classifying persons based on size. The Commission has the authority to establish rules and regulations based on factors such as size, scope, business model, compensation scheme, and systemic risk. Different requirements can be set for different classes of persons or matters, and terms can have different meanings, excluding the term 'client' for investors in private funds managed by investment advisers. The Commission, in consultation with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, will jointly establish rules within 12 months of the enactment of the Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009 to determine the form and content of reports required to be filed under sections 203(l). Investment advisers registered under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and the Commodity Exchange Act are required to file reports with the Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to assess the costs on industry members and investors due to registration and reporting requirements. A report will be submitted to Congress within 2 years. Effective date and transition period are also addressed. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; TRANSITION PERIOD. This Act and its amendments will take effect for investment advisers after a 1-year transition period. The Securities and Exchange Commission will provide rules for advisers to register before the deadline. SEC. 11. QUALIFIED CLIENT STANDARD. Section 205(e) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require the Commission to adjust for inflation every 5 years for any dollar amount test used in making determinations. Adjustments not multiples of $1,000 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000.
